#Text=3. Cooperative Localization
#Text=For range-free localization , a large deviation of distance estimation and position estimation may often happen , due to scarce information and difficult communication environment .
#Text=These unwelcome estimations are called outliers .
#Text=Especially in cooperative localization , outliers may lead to the failure of whole network .
#Text=To alleviate the effect of the outliers , we propose a cooperative localization method with outlier constraints .
#Text=Outlier constraints are divided into distance constraints and position constraints , which both rely on neighboring anchors .
#Text=The estimated distance and position will not exceed the communication range of neighboring anchors for both distance constraints and position constraints .
#Text=These constraints are represented by the parameters and , which condition the cooperative method .
#Text=The cooperative method introduces message passing and updates the estimated position through the variational message passing rule .
#Text=The final localization result depends on confidence of the agent to be located .
#Text=3.1. Outlier Constraints
#Text=For range-based localization , the estimated distances are relatively accurate , so that the localization of agents is quite precise .
#Text=For range-free localization , in our paper , the accuracy fails to meet the requirement of cooperative localization for both node distance and node position .

#Text=If the outlier distance and position are regarded as key information of a virtual anchor , this will cause a large derivation in the subsequent iteration , leading , finally , to disruption of the whole network and localization failure .
#Text=To avoid this problem , we propose the outlier constraint method , which includes position constraint and distance constraint .
#Text=It is inevitable to have low accuracy of distance estimation with the multi-hop method .
#Text=The outlier distance has a negative effect on cooperative localization , so it is better to exclude the outlier distances .
#Text=The outlier distance is excluded by constraints from anchors , as shown in
#Text=Figure 5
#Text=and
#Text=Figure 6

#Text=shows the distance between agent and anchor .
#Text=Figure 6

#Text=Hence , we propose a constraint function as ( 15 )

#Text=For the distance between agents , the outlier constraint is ( 16 ) where is the estimated distance according to Section 2 , denotes the neighboring anchors within communication range of , denotes the neighboring anchors within communication range of , denotes the real distance between any anchor in and any anchor in .
#Text=Hence , we propose the constraint function ( 17 )
#Text=In a cooperative network , the outlier position of the agent also has a negative effect on cooperative localization .
#Text=It is better to exclude these outlier positions through neighboring anchors .
#Text=In the network , agents can communicate with all nodes that are in their communication range .

#Text=Therefore , distance between the agent and its neighboring anchor is lower than the communication range : ( 18 ) where is the estimated position of agent , denotes the neighboring anchors within communication range of , denotes position of any anchor in .
#Text=Hence , we propose the constraint function ( 19 ) where is the Euclidean norm of estimated position and true position .
#Text=3.2. Cooperative Localization
#Text=Thanks to the locally factorized structure of the joint likelihood function , the cooperative localization problem can be addressed under the framework of factor graph .
#Text=Inference and estimation tasks are typically carried out on a factor graph by message passing between variable nodes and factor nodes .
#Text=Existing methods do not consider the outlier variable nodes and factor , which indicates that cooperative localization is not suitable for a range-free situation .
#Text=In the cooperative phase , we explore a hard decision-based cooperative way for a range-free situation applying outlier constraints .
#Text=We assume that the sensor node acquires a noisy measurement and that , which is the estimated distance from the sensor node ( can be either an agent or an anchor ) .
#Text=Then , we have ( 20 ) where is the measurement noise .
#Text=Without loss of generality , we assume that measurement noise obeys a Gaussian distribution , so ; is the standard deviation .
#Text=The probability density function of node distance is ( 21 )

#Text=We define and assume that the relative positions are conditionally independent and only depend on the two nodes involved : ( 22 ) where is defined as the position set of all nodes , and is defined as the distance set of all nodes .
